title: Font Name Conflicts
content:
So I've been wondering, when is it OK to use a name for a font that's already in use? Clearly you don't want to mess with that frothing-bastard-foundry in Chicago, but "Leviathan" for example is used just fine both by Hoefler and Agfa-Monotype. I can see practical problems when/if multiple fonts share a name on MyFonts for example, and I understand that the legal aspect can't be totally ignored, but I'm looking for some accounts of real-life experiences.   
   
In case you're wondering, specifically I'm debating if I should bother using "Pantagruel", which is being used by Scriptorium (at least). What's another good classical name for a really big guy?   
   
hhp

\> Mangonel   
   
Terms for medieval siege engines are often used indiscriminately. In this case by me as well... According to the indispensable "The Crossbow" (Sir Ralph Payne-Gallwey, 1903)\* a mangonel is a very large _catapult_, not a trebuchet. And I'm note sure which tended to _weigh_ more, but the trebuchet certainly was much taller and had a longer range.   
   
\* BTW, a careful reading of that book seems to indicate that the trebuchet was actually invented by Archimedes for the defense of his home town (which it did admirably), but was then lost to time until the Middle Ages - so it's much older than people say.   
   
\> too long and difficult   
   
But doesn't that make them more "thought-worthy"? When people wonder about how to pronounce a name, are they more turned on or off? Like I've thought of this font name -Recital- which I would "insist" that people pronounce like in French - "gheseetal". Not that I would try to even enforce that or throw a fit when I heard it misprononnced - just that that would generate interest. :-\>   
   
hhp
Trebuchets are marvellous things, unless you're on the receiving end. I've seen footage of one throwing a car about 200 yards.

Pronunciation can be an issue, as I learned when someone phoned Tiro to order the anus font. Anus font? Oh, Aeneas.   
   
Most people mispronounce Sylfaen, which is now installed on several million computers worldwide.   
   
You could name your typeface something deliberately unpronouncable, e.g. Xktrnbgr.

Xktrnbgr   
   
sound very good for a new successful typeface! ;-)
